2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDecision-making involves understanding how different variables affect each other and predicting the outcome when some of them are changed to new values. For instance, given an outcome variable, one may be interested in determining how a potential action(s) may affect it, understanding what led to its current value, or simulate what would happen if some variables are changed. Answering such questions requires causal reasoning. DoWhy is a Python library that guides you through the various steps of causal reasoning and provides a unified interface for answering causal questions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDoWhy provides a wide variety of algorithms for effect estimation, prediction, quantification\nof causal influences, diagnosis of causal structures, root cause analysis, interventions and\ncounterfactuals. A key feature of DoWhy is its refutation and falsification API that can test causal assumptions for any estimation method,\nthus making inference more robust and accessible to non-experts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGraphical Causal Models and Potential Outcomes: Best of both worlds\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDoWhy builds on two of the most powerful frameworks for causal inference:\ngraphical causal models and potential outcomes. For effect estimation, it uses graph-based criteria and do-calculus for\nmodeling assumptions and identifying a non-parametric causal effect. For estimation, it switches to methods based\nprimarily on potential outcomes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor causal questions beyond effect estimation, it uses the power of graphical causal models by modeling the data\ngeneration process via explicit causal mechanisms at each node, which, for instance, unlocks capabilities to attribute\nobserved effects to particular variables or estimate point-wise counterfactuals.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor a quick introduction to causal inference, check out \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/amit-sharma/causal-inference-tutorial/\"\u003eamit-sharma/causal-inference-tutorial\u003c/a\u003e\nWe also gave a more comprehensive tutorial at the ACM Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (\u003ca href=\"http://www.kdd.org/kdd2018/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eKDD 2018\u003c/a\u003e) conference: \u003ca href=\"http://causalinference.gitlab.io/kdd-tutorial/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ecausalinference.gitlab.io/kdd-tutorial\u003c/a\u003e.\nFor an introduction to the four steps of causal inference and its implications for machine learning, you can access this video tutorial from Microsoft Research \u003ca href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/video/foundations-of-causal-inference-and-its-impacts-on-machine-learning/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDoWhy Webinar\u003c/a\u003e and for an introduction to the graphical causal model API, see the \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=icpHrbDlGaw\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePyCon presentation on Root Cause Analysis with DoWhy\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-key-features\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDoWhy supports the following causal tasks:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eEffect estimation (identification, average causal effect, conditional average causal effect, instrumental variables and more)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eQuantify causal influences (mediation analysis, direct arrow strength, intrinsic causal influence)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhat-if analysis (generate samples from interventional distribution, estimate counterfactuals)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRoot cause analysis and explanations (attribute anomalies to their causes, find causes for changes in distributions, estimate feature relevance and more)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor more details and how to use these methods in practice, checkout the documentation at \u003ca href=\"https://py-why.github.io/dowhy/\" To install, you can use pip, poetry, or conda.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLatest Release\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eInstall the latest \u003ca href=\"https://pypi.org/project/dowhy/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003erelease\u003c/a\u003e using pip.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"pip install dowhy\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003epip install dowhy\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eInstall the latest \u003ca href=\"https://pypi.org/project/dowhy/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003erelease\u003c/a\u003e using poetry.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"poetry add dowhy\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003epoetry add dowhy\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eInstall the latest \u003ca href=\"https://anaconda.org/conda-forge/dowhy\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003erelease\u003c/a\u003e using conda.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"conda install -c conda-forge dowhy\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003econda install -c conda-forge dowhy\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you face \"Solving environment\" problems with conda, then try \u003ccode\u003econda update --all\u003c/code\u003e and then install dowhy. If that does not work, then use \u003ccode\u003econda config --set channel_priority false\u003c/code\u003e and try to install again. If the problem persists, please \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/microsoft/dowhy/issues/197\" data-hovercard-type=\"issue\" data-hovercard-url=\"/py-why/dowhy/issues/197/hovercard\"\u003eadd your issue here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDevelopment Version\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you prefer to use the latest dev version, your dependency management tool will need to point at our GitHub repository.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"pip install git+https://github.com/py-why/dowhy@main\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003epip install git+https://github.com/py-why/dowhy@main\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRequirements\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDoWhy requires a few dependencies.\nDetails on specific versions can be found in \u003ca href=\"/py-why/dowhy/blob/main/pyproject.toml\"\u003epyproject.toml\u003c/a\u003e, under the tool.poetry.dependencies section.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you face any problems, try installing dependencies manually.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"pip install '\u0026lt;dependency-name\u0026gt;==\u0026lt;version\u0026gt;'\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003epip install \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u0026lt;dependency-name\u0026gt;==\u0026lt;version\u0026gt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e'\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOptionally, if you wish to input graphs in the dot format, then install pydot (or pygraphviz).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor better-looking graphs, you can optionally install pygraphviz. Here, we exemplarily estimate the causal effect of\na treatment on an outcome variable:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"from dowhy import CausalModel\nimport dowhy.datasets\n\n# Load some sample data\ndata = dowhy.datasets.linear_dataset(\n    beta=10,\n    num_common_causes=5,\n    num_instruments=2,\n    num_samples=10000,\n    treatment_is_binary=True)\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003efrom\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edowhy\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCausalModel\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-k\"\u003eimport\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edowhy\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edatasets\u003c/span\u003e\n\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c\"\u003e# Load some sample data\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edata\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edowhy\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edatasets\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-en\"\u003elinear_dataset\u003c/span\u003e(\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ebeta\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e10\u003c/span\u003e,\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003enum_common_causes\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e5\u003c/span\u003e,\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003enum_instruments\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e2\u003c/span\u003e,\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003enum_samples\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e10000\u003c/span\u003e,\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003etreatment_is_binary\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003eTrue\u003c/span\u003e)\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA causal graph can be defined in different way, but the most common way is via \u003ca href=\"https://networkx.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eNetworkX\u003c/a\u003e.\nAfter loading in the data, we use the four main operations for effect estimation in DoWhy: \u003cem\u003emodel\u003c/em\u003e, \u003cem\u003eidentify\u003c/em\u003e,\n\u003cem\u003eestimate\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003erefute\u003c/em\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"# I. Create a causal model from the data and given graph.\nmodel = CausalModel(\n    data=data[\u0026quot;df\u0026quot;],\n    treatment=data[\u0026quot;treatment_name\u0026quot;],\n    outcome=data[\u0026quot;outcome_name\u0026quot;],\n    graph=data[\u0026quot;gml_graph\u0026quot;])  # Or alternatively, as nx.DiGraph\n\n# II. Identify causal effect and return target estimands\nidentified_estimand = model.identify_effect()\n\n# III. Estimate the target estimand using a statistical method.\nestimate = model.estimate_effect(identified_estimand,\n                                 method_name=\u0026quot;backdoor.propensity_score_matching\u0026quot;)\n\n# IV. Refute the obtained estimate using multiple robustness checks.\nrefute_results = model.refute_estimate(identified_estimand, estimate,\n                                       method_name=\u0026quot;random_common_cause\u0026quot;)\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c\"\u003e# I. Create a causal model from the data and given graph.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emodel\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eCausalModel\u003c/span\u003e(\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edata\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edata\u003c/span\u003e[\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"df\"\u003c/span\u003e],\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003etreatment\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edata\u003c/span\u003e[\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"treatment_name\"\u003c/span\u003e],\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eoutcome\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edata\u003c/span\u003e[\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"outcome_name\"\u003c/span\u003e],\n    \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003egraph\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edata\u003c/span\u003e[\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"gml_graph\"\u003c/span\u003e])  \u003cspan class=\"pl-c\"\u003e# Or alternatively, as nx.DiGraph\u003c/span\u003e\n\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c\"\u003e# II. Estimate the target estimand using a statistical method.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eestimate\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emodel\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-en\"\u003eestimate_effect\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eidentified_estimand\u003c/span\u003e,\n                                 \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emethod_name\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"backdoor.propensity_score_matching\"\u003c/span\u003e)\n\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c\"\u003e# IV. Refute the obtained estimate using multiple robustness checks.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003erefute_results\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emodel\u003c/span\u003e.\u003cspan class=\"pl-en\"\u003erefute_estimate\u003c/span\u003e(\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eidentified_estimand\u003c/span\u003e, \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eestimate\u003c/span\u003e,\n                                       \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emethod_name\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\"random_common_cause\"\u003c/span\u003e)\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDoWhy stresses on the interpretability of its output. At any point in the analysis,\nyou can inspect the untested assumptions, identified estimands (if any), and the\nestimate (if any). address causal questions beyond effect estimation.\nIt is based on Pearl's graphical causal model framework and models the causal data generation process of each variable\nexplicitly via \u003cem\u003ecausal mechanisms\u003c/em\u003e to support a wide range of causal algorithms. For more details, see the book\n\u003ca href=\"https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262037310/elements-of-causal-inference/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eElements of Causal Inference\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eComplex causal queries, such as attributing observed anomalies to nodes in the system, can be performed with just a few\nlines of code:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"import networkx as nx, numpy as np, pandas as pd\nfrom dowhy import gcm\n\n# Let's generate some \u0026quot;normal\u0026quot; data we assume we're given from our problem domain:\nX = np.random.normal(loc=0, scale=1, size=1000)\nY = 2 * X + np.random.normal(loc=0, scale=1, size=1000)\nZ = 3 * Y + np.random.normal(loc=0, scale=1, size=1000)\ndata = pd.DataFrame(dict(X=X, Y=Y, Z=Z))\n\n# 1. Modeling cause-effect relationships as a structural causal model\n#    (causal graph + functional causal models):\ncausal_model = gcm.StructuralCausalModel(nx.DiGraph([('X', 'Y'), ('Y', 'Z')]))  # X -\u0026gt; Y -\u0026gt; Z\ngcm.auto.assign_causal_mechanisms(causal_model, data)\n\n# 2. Fitting the SCM to the data:\ngcm.fit(causal_model, data)\n\n# Optional: Evaluate causal model\nprint(gcm.evaluate_causal_model(causal_model, data))\n\n# Step 3: Perform a causal analysis.\n# results = gcm.\u0026lt;causal_query\u0026gt;(causal_model, ...)\n# For instance, root cause analysis:\nanomalous_sample = pd.DataFrame(dict(X=[0.1], Y=[6.2], Z=[19]))  # Here, Y is the root cause.\n\n# \u0026quot;Which node is the root cause of the anomaly in Z?\u0026quot;:\nanomaly_attribution = gcm.attribute_anomalies(causal_model, \u0026quot;Z\u0026quot;, anomalous_sample)\n\n# Or sampling from an interventional distribution. Here, under the intervention do(Y := 2).\nsamples = gcm.interventional_samples(causal_model, interventions={'Y': lambda y: 2}, num_samples_to_draw=100)\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Decision-making involves understanding how different variables affect each other and predicting the outcome when some of them are changed to new values. For instance, given an outcome variable, one may be interested in determining how a potential action(s) may affect it, understanding what led to its current value, or simulate what would happen if some variables are changed. Answering such questions requires causal reasoning. DoWhy is a Python library that guides you through the various steps of causal reasoning and provides a unified interface for answering causal questions.</p><p dir="auto">DoWhy provides a wide variety of algorithms for effect estimation, prediction, quantificationof causal influences, diagnosis of causal structures, root cause analysis, interventions andcounterfactuals. A key feature of DoWhy is its refutation and falsification API that can test causal assumptions for any estimation method,thus making inference more robust and accessible to non-experts.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Graphical Causal Models and Potential Outcomes: Best of both worlds</strong></p><p dir="auto">DoWhy builds on two of the most powerful frameworks for causal inference:graphical causal models and potential outcomes. For effect estimation, it uses graph-based criteria and do-calculus formodeling assumptions and identifying a non-parametric causal effect. For estimation, it switches to methods basedprimarily on potential outcomes.</p><p dir="auto">For causal questions beyond effect estimation, it uses the power of graphical causal models by modeling the datageneration process via explicit causal mechanisms at each node, which, for instance, unlocks capabilities to attributeobserved effects to particular variables or estimate point-wise counterfactuals.</p><p dir="auto">For a quick introduction to causal inference, check out <a href="https://github.com/amit-sharma/causal-inference-tutorial/">amit-sharma/causal-inference-tutorial</a>We also gave a more comprehensive tutorial at the ACM Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining (<a href="http://www.kdd.org/kdd2018/" rel="nofollow">KDD 2018</a>) conference: <a href="http://causalinference.gitlab.io/kdd-tutorial/" rel="nofollow">causalinference.gitlab.io/kdd-tutorial</a>.For an introduction to the four steps of causal inference and its implications for machine learning, you can access this video tutorial from Microsoft Research <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/video/foundations-of-causal-inference-and-its-impacts-on-machine-learning/" rel="nofollow">DoWhy Webinar</a> and for an introduction to the graphical causal model API, see the <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=icpHrbDlGaw" rel="nofollow">PyCon presentation on Root Cause Analysis with DoWhy</a>.</p><a name="user-content-key-features"></a><div dir="auto"><li>Effect estimation (identification, average causal effect, conditional average causal effect, instrumental variables and more)</li><li>Quantify causal influences (mediation analysis, direct arrow strength, intrinsic causal influence)</li><li>What-if analysis (generate samples from interventional distribution, estimate counterfactuals)</li><li>Root cause analysis and explanations (attribute anomalies to their causes, find causes for changes in distributions, estimate feature relevance and more)</li></ul><p dir="auto">For more details and how to use these methods in practice, To install, you can use pip, poetry, or conda.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Latest Release</strong></p><p dir="auto">Install the latest <a href="https://pypi.org/project/dowhy/" rel="nofollow">release</a> using pip.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="pip install dowhy"><pre>pip install dowhy</pre></div><p dir="auto">Install the latest <a href="https://pypi.org/project/dowhy/" rel="nofollow">release</a> using poetry.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="poetry add dowhy"><pre>poetry add dowhy</pre></div><p dir="auto">Install the latest <a href="https://anaconda.org/conda-forge/dowhy" rel="nofollow">release</a> using conda.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="conda install -c conda-forge dowhy"><pre>conda install -c conda-forge dowhy</pre></div><p dir="auto">If you face "Solving environment" problems with conda, then try <code>conda update --all</code> and then install dowhy. If that does not work, then use <code>conda config --set channel_priority false</code> and try to install again. If the problem persists, please <a href="https://github.com/microsoft/dowhy/issues/197" data-hovercard-type="issue" data-hovercard-url="/py-why/dowhy/issues/197/hovercard">add your issue here</a>.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Development Version</strong></p><p dir="auto">If you prefer to use the latest dev version, your dependency management tool will need to point at our GitHub repository.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="pip install git+https://github.com/py-why/dowhy@main"><pre>pip install git+https://github.com/py-why/dowhy@main</pre></div><p dir="auto"><strong>Requirements</strong></p><p dir="auto">DoWhy requires a few dependencies.Details on specific versions can be found in <a href="/py-why/dowhy/blob/main/pyproject.toml">pyproject.toml</a>, under the tool.poetry.dependencies section.</p><p dir="auto">If you face any problems, try installing dependencies manually.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="pip install '<dependency-name>==<version>'"><pre>pip install <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><dependency-name>==<version><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span></pre></div><p dir="auto">Optionally, if you wish to input graphs in the dot format, then install pydot (or pygraphviz).</p><p dir="auto">For better-looking graphs, you can optionally install pygraphviz. require a few lines of code to write. Here, we exemplarily estimate the causal effect ofa treatment on an outcome variable:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from dowhy import CausalModelimport dowhy.datasets# Load some sample datadata = dowhy.datasets.linear_dataset(    beta=10,    num_common_causes=5,    num_instruments=2,    num_samples=10000,    treatment_is_binary=True)"><pre><span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s1">dowhy</span> <span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-v">CausalModel</span><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-s1">dowhy</span>.<span class="pl-s1">datasets</span><span class="pl-c"># Load some sample data</span><span class="pl-s1">data</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">dowhy</span>.<span class="pl-s1">datasets</span>.<span class="pl-en">linear_dataset</span>(    <span class="pl-s1">beta</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">10</span>,    <span class="pl-s1">num_common_causes</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">5</span>,    <span class="pl-s1">num_instruments</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">2</span>,    <span class="pl-s1">num_samples</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">10000</span>,    <span class="pl-s1">treatment_is_binary</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">True</span>)</pre></div><p dir="auto">A causal graph can be defined in different way, but the most common way is via <a href="https://networkx.org/" rel="nofollow">NetworkX</a>.After loading in the data, we use the four main operations for effect estimation in DoWhy: <em>model</em>, <em>identify</em>,<em>estimate</em> and <em>refute</em>:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="# I. Create a causal model from the data and given graph.model = CausalModel(    data=data["df"],    treatment=data["treatment_name"],    outcome=data["outcome_name"],    graph=data["gml_graph"])  # Or alternatively, as nx.DiGraph# II. Identify causal effect and return target estimandsidentified_estimand = model.identify_effect()# III. Estimate the target estimand using a statistical method.estimate = model.estimate_effect(identified_estimand,                                 method_name="backdoor.propensity_score_matching")# IV. Refute the obtained estimate using multiple robustness checks.refute_results = model.refute_estimate(identified_estimand, estimate,                                       method_name="random_common_cause")"><pre><span class="pl-c"># I. Create a causal model from the data and given graph.</span><span class="pl-s1">model</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-v">CausalModel</span>(    <span class="pl-s1">data</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s1">data</span>[<span class="pl-s">"df"</span>],    <span class="pl-s1">treatment</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s1">data</span>[<span class="pl-s">"treatment_name"</span>],    <span class="pl-s1">outcome</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s1">data</span>[<span class="pl-s">"outcome_name"</span>],    <span class="pl-s1">graph</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s1">data</span>[<span class="pl-s">"gml_graph"</span>])  <span class="pl-c"># Or alternatively, as nx.DiGraph</span><span class="pl-c"># II. Identify causal effect and return target estimands</span><span class="pl-s1">identified_estimand</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">model</span>.<span class="pl-en">identify_effect</span>()<span class="pl-c"># III. Estimate the target estimand using a statistical method.</span><span class="pl-s1">estimate</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">model</span>.<span class="pl-en">estimate_effect</span>(<span class="pl-s1">identified_estimand</span>,                                 <span class="pl-s1">method_name</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"backdoor.propensity_score_matching"</span>)<span class="pl-c"># IV. Refute the obtained estimate using multiple robustness checks.</span><span class="pl-s1">refute_results</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">model</span>.<span class="pl-en">refute_estimate</span>(<span class="pl-s1">identified_estimand</span>, <span class="pl-s1">estimate</span>,                                       <span class="pl-s1">method_name</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-s">"random_common_cause"</span>)</pre></div><p dir="auto">DoWhy stresses on the interpretability of its output. At any point in the analysis,you can inspect the untested assumptions, identified estimands (if any), and theestimate (if any). Here's a sample output of the linear regression estimator:</p><p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer nofollow" href="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/py-why/dowhy/main/docs/images/regression_output.png"><img alt="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/py-why/dowhy/main/docs/images/regression_output.png" src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/py-why/dowhy/main/docs/images/regression_output.png" style="width: 80%; max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto">For a full code example, check out the <a href="https://www.pywhy.org/dowhy/main/example_notebooks/dowhy_simple_example.html" rel="nofollow">Getting Started with DoWhy</a> notebook.</p><p dir="auto">You can also use Conditional Average Treatment Effect (CATE) estimation methods from <a href="https://github.com/py-why/econml">EconML</a>, as shown in the <a href="https://www.pywhy.org/dowhy/main/example_notebooks/dowhy-conditional-treatment-effects.html" rel="nofollow">Conditional Treatment Effects</a> notebook. href="#example-graphical-causal-model-gcm-based-inference"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">DoWhy's graphical causal model framework offers powerful tools to address causal questions beyond effect estimation.It is based on Pearl's graphical causal model framework and models the causal data generation process of each variableexplicitly via <em>causal mechanisms</em> to support a wide range of causal algorithms. For more details, see the book<a href="https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262037310/elements-of-causal-inference/" rel="nofollow">Elements of Causal Inference</a>.</p><p dir="auto">Complex causal queries, such as attributing observed anomalies to nodes in the system, can be performed with just a fewlines of code:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import networkx as nx, numpy as np, pandas as pdfrom dowhy import gcm# Let's generate some "normal" data we assume we're given from our problem domain:X = np.random.normal(loc=0, scale=1, size=1000)Y = 2 * X + np.random.normal(loc=0, scale=1, size=1000)Z = 3 * Y + np.random.normal(loc=0, scale=1, size=1000)data = pd.DataFrame(dict(X=X, Y=Y, Z=Z))# 1. Modeling cause-effect relationships as a structural causal model#    (causal graph + functional causal models):causal_model = gcm.StructuralCausalModel(nx.DiGraph([('X', 'Y'), ('Y', 'Z')]))  # X -> Y -> Zgcm.auto.assign_causal_mechanisms(causal_model, data)# 2. Fitting the SCM to the data:gcm.fit(causal_model, data)# Optional: Evaluate causal modelprint(gcm.evaluate_causal_model(causal_model, data))# Step 3: Perform a causal analysis.# results = gcm.<causal_query>(causal_model, ...)# For instance, root cause analysis:anomalous_sample = pd.DataFrame(dict(X=[0.1], Y=[6.2], Z=[19]))  # Here, Y is the root cause.# "Which node is the root cause of the anomaly in Z?":anomaly_attribution = gcm.attribute_anomalies(causal_model, "Z", anomalous_sample)# Or sampling from an interventional distribution. Here, under the intervention do(Y := 2).samples = gcm.interventional_samples(causal_model, interventions={'Y': lambda y: 2}, num_samples_to_draw=100)"><pre><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-s1">networkx</span> <span class="pl-k">as</span> <span class="pl-s1">nx</span>, <span class="pl-s1">numpy</span> <span class="pl-k">as</span> <span class="pl-s1">np</span>, <span class="pl-s1">pandas</span> <span class="pl-k">as</span> <span class="pl-s1">pd</span><span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s1">dowhy</span> <span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-s1">gcm</span><span class="pl-c"># Let's generate some "normal" data we assume we're given from our problem domain:</span><span class="pl-v">X</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">np</span>.<span class="pl-s1">random</span>.<span class="pl-en">normal</span>(<span class="pl-s1">loc</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">0</span>, <span class="pl-s1">scale</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>, <span class="pl-s1">size</span><span class="pl-c1">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1000</span>)<span
